questions.question: An agency relationship is created when:

options.B: One person (agent) agrees to act on behalf of another (principal) subject to the principal's control
options.D: A written agreement is filed with the state

questions.explanation: An agency relationship exists when: (1) there is mutual consent, (2) the agent acts on behalf of the principal, and (3) the principal has the right to control the agent's actions. Writing, consideration, and filing are not required.
questions.tip: Agency = consent + acting on behalf + principal control. No writing or payment required.

questions.question: Express authority is:

options.B: Authority explicitly granted by the principal to the agent
options.C: Authority based on the agent's past actions
options.D: Authority implied from the agency relationship

questions.explanation: Express authority is authority that the principal explicitly grants to the agent, either orally or in writing. The principal directly communicates what the agent is authorized to do.
questions.tip: Express authority = principal directly tells agent what they can do (oral or written).

questions.question: A general agent is authorized to:

options.B: Conduct a series of transactions involving continuity of service

questions.explanation: A general agent has authority to conduct a series of transactions involving continuity of service (e.g., manager). A special agent is authorized for only one or a few specific transactions (e.g., selling a house).
questions.tip: General agent = ongoing authority. Special agent = specific transaction(s) only.

questions.question: A principal's primary duty to an agent includes:

options.B: Compensation if agreed upon and reimbursement for authorized expenses

questions.explanation: Principal's duties to agent include: (1) compensation (if agreed), (2) reimbursement for authorized expenses, (3) indemnification for losses incurred in following lawful instructions, and (4) cooperation in performance.
questions.tip: Principal owes agent: Pay (if agreed), reimburse expenses, indemnify for authorized acts, cooperate.

questions.question: An agent's fiduciary duty to the principal includes:

options.A: Acting in the agent's own best interest
options.B: Loyalty and acting in the principal's best interest

questions.explanation: The agent owes fiduciary duties including: loyalty (no self-dealing or conflicts), obedience, care, accounting, and notification. The agent must put the principal's interests above their own.
questions.tip: Agent is fiduciary: Loyalty, obedience, care, accounting, notification. Principal's interests first!

questions.question: An agency relationship automatically terminates by operation of law upon:

options.B: Death of either the principal or agent

questions.explanation: Agency terminates by operation of law upon: death of principal or agent, incapacity of either party, impossibility of performance, bankruptcy of principal (and sometimes agent), or war between principal and agent's countries.
questions.tip: Agency ends automatically: Death, incapacity, impossibility, bankruptcy. No notice needed.

questions.question: Implied authority includes authority that is:

options.B: Reasonably necessary to carry out express authority
options.C: Created by third party expectations only

questions.explanation: Implied authority is authority that is reasonably necessary to accomplish expressly authorized tasks, consistent with custom and practice, or naturally flowing from the nature of the agency relationship.
questions.tip: Implied authority = what's reasonably necessary to do the job. Incidental powers.

questions.question: Apparent authority exists when:

options.A: The agent believes they have authority
options.B: The principal's conduct leads a third party to reasonably believe the agent has authority
options.D: The agent has worked for the principal for many years

questions.explanation: Apparent authority arises from the principal's manifestations to third parties that reasonably lead them to believe an agent has authority. It can bind the principal even if the agent lacks actual authority.
questions.tip: Apparent authority: Principal's conduct + third party's reasonable belief. Can bind principal!

questions.question: When an agent acts for a disclosed principal with authority, who is liable on the contract?

options.B: Only the principal

questions.explanation: When an agent acts with authority for a disclosed principal (third party knows both that there is a principal and the principal's identity), only the principal is liable on the contract. The agent drops out of the transaction.
questions.tip: Disclosed principal + authority = principal liable, agent not liable. Agent drops out.

questions.question: When an agent contracts on behalf of an undisclosed principal:

options.B: Only the agent is liable
options.C: Both the agent and principal may be liable to the third party

questions.explanation: When the principal is undisclosed (third party doesn't know there is a principal), both the agent and principal may be liable. The third party can elect to hold either liable once the principal's identity is discovered.
questions.tip: Undisclosed principal: Third party can sue either agent or principal. Must elect one.

questions.question: For a principal to ratify an unauthorized act of an agent, the principal must:

options.B: Have knowledge of material facts and ratify the entire transaction

questions.explanation: Ratification requires: (1) principal has knowledge of material facts, (2) principal accepts the entire transaction (can't ratify part), (3) principal had capacity at time of act and ratification, and (4) act was legal.
questions.tip: Ratification: Full knowledge + accept entire deal + capacity + legal act. Relates back!

questions.question: Under respondeat superior, an employer is liable for an employee's torts if:

options.A: The tort occurred at any time
options.B: The tort occurred within the scope of employment
options.C: The employee was an independent contractor

questions.explanation: Respondeat superior makes employers vicariously liable for employee torts committed within the scope of employment. Factors include whether conduct was of the type employed to perform, occurred during work time/place, and was motivated by serving the employer.
questions.tip: Respondeat superior: Employer liable for employee torts within scope of employment.

questions.question: A principal generally is NOT vicariously liable for the torts of:

options.B: Servants

questions.explanation: A principal is generally not vicariously liable for torts of independent contractors because the principal lacks control over how the work is performed. Exceptions: inherently dangerous activities, non-delegable duties, and negligent selection.
questions.tip: Independent contractors: Principal usually not liable for their torts. Exceptions for dangerous activities.

questions.question: The most important factor in distinguishing an employee from an independent contractor is:

options.A: Whether the worker is paid hourly or by the job
options.B: The degree of control the principal has over how the work is performed

questions.explanation: The key factor is the principal's right to control the manner and method of work performance. With employees, the principal controls how work is done. With independent contractors, the principal controls only the result, not the method.
questions.tip: Employee vs IC: Control over method = employee. Control only over result = IC.

questions.question: An agent's duty to account requires the agent to:

options.A: Prepare tax returns for the principal
options.B: Keep accurate records and account for all property and money received
options.D: File annual reports with the state

questions.explanation: The duty to account requires agents to keep accurate records of all transactions, account for money and property belonging to the principal, and not commingle the principal's assets with their own.
questions.tip: Duty to account: Track principal's money/property, keep records, don't commingle funds.

questions.question: An agency coupled with an interest:

options.A: Can be revoked at any time by the principal
options.B: Cannot be revoked by the principal without the agent's consent
options.C: Terminates upon death of the principal

questions.explanation: An agency coupled with an interest (where the agent has a security interest in the subject matter of the agency) cannot be unilaterally revoked by the principal. It also survives the principal's death and incapacity. Example: power of attorney to sell property securing a debt.
questions.tip: Agency coupled with interest: Irrevocable. Agent has stake in subject matter. Survives death.

questions.question: When a principal is partially disclosed (third party knows there's a principal but not their identity):

options.B: Only the agent is liable
options.C: Both agent and principal may be liable

questions.explanation: With a partially disclosed principal (third party knows an agency exists but not the principal's identity), both the agent and principal may be held liable on the contract. This protects the third party who couldn't fully evaluate the principal.
questions.tip: Partially disclosed: Third party knows there's a principal but not who. Both may be liable.

questions.question: A durable power of attorney:

options.B: Remains effective despite the principal's subsequent incapacity
options.C: Is only valid for one year

questions.explanation: A durable power of attorney includes language stating it survives the principal's incapacity. This allows the agent to continue acting when the principal becomes unable to manage affairs. Non-durable powers terminate upon incapacity.
questions.tip: Durable POA: Survives principal's incapacity. Must specifically state it's durable.

questions.question: An agent who acts without authority may be liable to the third party for:

options.B: Breach of warranty of authority

questions.explanation: An agent who purports to act with authority implicitly warrants to third parties that they have such authority. If the agent lacks authority and the principal is not bound, the agent is liable for breach of this warranty of authority.
questions.tip: Agent warrants authority to third parties. If no authority, agent liable for breach of warranty.

questions.question: After termination of an agency, apparent authority continues until:

options.B: Third parties receive actual or constructive notice of termination
options.D: The principal publishes notice in a legal newspaper

questions.explanation: After termination, apparent authority continues as to third parties until they receive notice. Those who previously dealt with the agent need actual notice. Others may receive constructive notice (e.g., newspaper publication).
questions.tip: After termination: Give actual notice to prior dealers, constructive notice to others.

questions.question: An agent may appoint a subagent when:

options.B: Authorized by the principal, by custom, or when necessary due to unforeseen circumstances
options.C: The agent wants to take time off
options.D: The subagent is a family member

questions.explanation: Agents can appoint subagents when: (1) expressly authorized, (2) implied by custom or trade, or (3) necessary due to unforeseen circumstances. The subagent owes duties to both the agent and principal.
questions.tip: Subagents: OK if authorized, customary, or emergency. Subagent owes duties to both.

questions.question: An agent's duty of obedience requires the agent to:

options.A: Follow all instructions, including illegal ones
options.B: Follow all reasonable and lawful instructions from the principal

questions.explanation: The duty of obedience requires agents to follow all reasonable and lawful instructions. Agents should not follow instructions that are illegal, unethical, or outside the scope of authority. Agents may deviate in emergencies.
questions.tip: Obedience: Follow lawful, reasonable instructions. Don't obey illegal orders.

questions.question: An employer is generally NOT liable for an employee's torts during a 'frolic' because:

options.B: The employee substantially departed from the scope of employment for personal reasons
options.C: The employer didn't authorize the specific act
options.D: The victim should have known better

questions.explanation: A 'frolic' is a substantial departure from employment duties for personal purposes, taking the employee outside the scope of employment. A 'detour' is a minor deviation that may still be within scope. Frolics = no employer liability.
questions.tip: Frolic = major personal departure (no liability). Detour = minor deviation (still liable).

questions.question: Agency by estoppel arises when:

options.B: A principal's conduct leads a third party to reasonably believe an agency exists, and the third party detrimentally relies
options.C: The parties sign an agency agreement
options.D: An agent acts without any authority

questions.explanation: Agency by estoppel occurs when: (1) principal's acts or failure to act create appearance of agency, (2) third party reasonably relies on that appearance, and (3) third party changes position to their detriment. The principal is estopped from denying agency.
questions.tip: Estoppel: Principal's conduct + third party reliance + detriment = can't deny agency.

questions.question: An agent who commits a tort while acting for the principal is:

options.A: Never personally liable because they were acting for the principal
options.B: Always personally liable for their own torts
options.C: Liable only if the principal is insolvent

questions.explanation: An agent is always personally liable for their own torts, regardless of whether they were acting within the scope of employment. The fact that the principal may also be vicariously liable does not shield the agent from personal liability.
questions.tip: Agent always liable for own torts. 'I was just following orders' is no defense.

questions.question: Under the equal dignities rule, if a contract must be in writing:

options.A: The agency relationship need not be in writing
options.B: The agent's authority must also be in writing
options.C: Only the agent needs to sign
options.D: The contract can be oral if the agent is present

questions.explanation: The equal dignities rule requires that if a contract must be in writing under the Statute of Frauds, the agent's authority to enter that contract must also be in writing. Example: Agent selling real property needs written authority.
questions.tip: Equal dignities: Contract needs writing → authority needs writing. Real estate = written POA.

questions.question: When a principal ratifies an unauthorized act, the ratification:

options.A: Is effective only from the date of ratification
options.B: Relates back to the time of the original act
options.C: Must be approved by the third party

questions.explanation: Ratification relates back to the time of the original unauthorized act, making it as if the agent had authority from the beginning. This creates rights and liabilities as of the original transaction date.
questions.tip: Ratification relates back. Treated as if authorized from the start.

questions.question: If an agent has a conflict of interest with the principal, the agent must:

options.B: Fully disclose the conflict and obtain the principal's informed consent
options.C: Proceed without disclosure if the conflict is minor
options.D: Report to the appropriate government agency

questions.explanation: When a conflict of interest exists, the agent must make full disclosure to the principal. With informed consent, the agent may proceed. Acting without disclosure is a breach of the duty of loyalty, and any transaction may be voided.
questions.tip: Conflict of interest: Must disclose fully. Get principal's informed consent before proceeding.

questions.question: If a principal wrongfully terminates an agency contract before its term expires:

options.A: The termination is void and the agency continues
options.B: The agency ends but the principal is liable for breach of contract damages
options.C: The agent can force the principal to continue the relationship

questions.explanation: A principal always has the power to terminate an agency (unless coupled with an interest), but may not have the right. Wrongful termination ends the agency but exposes the principal to breach of contract damages to the agent.
questions.tip: Principal has power to terminate, but may owe damages if no right to terminate.

questions.question: An employer may be liable for an employee's intentional torts if:

options.B: The conduct was foreseeable based on the nature of employment or in furtherance of business
options.C: Only if the employer specifically authorized the tort
options.D: The employee was on lunch break

questions.explanation: Employers may be liable for employees' intentional torts if: (1) force is authorized (bouncer), (2) friction is inherent in the job (collection agent), (3) employee advances employer's interests, or (4) employer is negligent in hiring/supervision.
questions.tip: Intentional torts: Employer liable if foreseeable in nature of job or advancing employer's purpose.

questions.question: Under modern law, an electronic agent (automated system) can:

options.B: Bind the principal to contracts formed through automated processes

questions.explanation: UETA and ESIGN recognize electronic agents (computer programs) as capable of forming binding contracts. A principal who programs or uses an electronic agent is bound by contracts the system makes according to its programming.
questions.tip: Electronic agents can form binding contracts. Principal responsible for system's actions.

questions.question: An agent generally has no duty to disclose the principal's identity unless:

options.B: The agent is dealing in their own name and concealment would be fraudulent
options.D: The principal is located out of state

questions.explanation: While agents generally can act for undisclosed principals, they cannot engage in fraud. If non-disclosure would constitute fraud (misrepresentation, confidential relationship), the agent must disclose. Also, certain fiduciary dealings require disclosure.
questions.tip: Can act for undisclosed principal, but can't commit fraud through non-disclosure.

questions.question: Under the concept of inherent agency power (Restatement 2nd), a principal may be bound by an agent's unauthorized act when:

options.A: Never, unless there is actual authority
options.B: The agent acts within the usual scope of similar agents, even without actual or apparent authority

questions.explanation: Inherent agency power (recognized in Restatement 2nd) binds principals when agents act within the usual scope of their type of agency, protecting third parties who reasonably expect such authority. Restatement 3rd eliminated this doctrine, relying on apparent authority.
questions.tip: Inherent power: General agent acting in usual way may bind principal. Protects third parties.

questions.question: After an agency relationship terminates, the agent's duty of confidentiality:

options.B: Continues indefinitely for trade secrets and confidential information
options.D: Applies only if there's a written agreement

questions.explanation: The duty of confidentiality survives termination of the agency. Former agents cannot disclose or use the principal's trade secrets and confidential information. General skills and knowledge acquired may be used.
questions.tip: Confidentiality survives termination. Can't use trade secrets. General skills OK.

questions.question: Knowledge acquired by an agent within the scope of agency is:

options.B: Generally imputed to the principal

questions.explanation: Under the imputed knowledge doctrine, notice or knowledge acquired by an agent within the scope of agency is imputed to the principal, even if the agent fails to communicate it. Exceptions: agent is acting adversely to principal's interests.
questions.tip: Agent's knowledge = principal's knowledge (usually). Principal can't claim ignorance.
